awd_titl_txt: Optimization and Statistical Procedures for Big Data and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
In the era of big data, data sets may be massive in size and have high dimensionality. Examples include social media data, high-resolution image data, and genomic data. High dimensionality and massive sample size pose great computational and statistical challenges. This project aims to investigate novel optimization techniques and statistical analytic tools for big data collected in important applications. The project will significantly enhance the capabilities of optimization and statistics in analyzing big data. Results of the project are anticipated to benefit a broad range of areas including public health, medical studies, and financial portfolio management.

This project consists of three sub-projects to advance knowledge in modern optimization techniques and statistical procedures for big data. (1) The project studies a unified framework for high-dimensional constrained regularization, and further investigates the statistical performance of a general framework for high-dimensional data under folded concave penalty and fixed constraints. (2) The project explores efficient distributed algorithms for constrained statistical learning, investigating communication-efficient sample-splitting algorithms to handle the vast number of samples and high communication cost in high-dimensional constrained regularization problems with folded concave penalty. The project will study the convergence of the new algorithms for non-convex learning as well as statistical convergence. The work demonstrates the necessity to consider statistical analysis and optimization analysis simultaneously. (3) The investigators plan to apply the methodology in analyzing big data sets to address clinical and scientific questions related to Parkinson's disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project are to (1) investigate new optimization techniques and statistical analytic tools for big data analysis with high-dimension and massive data through interdisciplinary collaboration between statisticians and engineers, and (2) to apply the new optimization and statistical procedures to analyze big data collected in real world applications including analysis for biomarker identification problems in health care through interdisciplinary collaboration among statisticians, engineers and neuroscientists

The research team of this project has published more than 42 scientific papers under this project support. More specifically, we provide a brief summary below:

Statistical Inference procedures for high-dimensional data: We developed
several tests of linear hypotheses for ultrahigh dimensional generalized linear models in Shi, Song, Chen and Li (2019, Ann Stat.). We also developed hypothesis testing on linear structures of high dimensional covariance matrix in Zheng, Chen, Cui and Li (2019, Ann Stat). Our work on statistical inference for high-dimensional data includes Fang, Ning and Li (2020, Ann. Stat.) , Zhou, Zhu, Zu and Li, (2020, JASA), Cui, Li, Yang and Zhou (2020, Biometrika), Xiao, Ke and Li (2021, JMLR), Shi, Song, Lu and Li (2021, JASA), Li Wang and Li (2021, Ann Stat); Liu, Yu and Li (2022, JMLR), Huang, Li, Li and Yang (2022, JMVA) and Li, Xu, Zhou and Zhu (2023, JASA).


Algorithms: We have developed new algorithm for high-dimensional folder concave penalized least squares function in Liu, Wang, Yao, Li and Ye (2019, Math. Programming). We also developed a new algorithm for online sufficient dimension reduction through sliced inverse regression in Cai, Li and Zhu (2020, JMLR).

Feature screening and variable selection: We developed a distributed feature screening procedure for ultrahigh dimensional big data in Li, Li, Xia and Xu (2020, JMLR). We develop feature selection procedure for longitudinal high dimensional data under the framework of generalized varying coefficient mixed effect model, and further applied the new procedure to obesity GWAS in Chu, Li, Liu and Reimherr (2020). We developed a variable selection for ultrahigh dimensional partial linear model via partial correlation in Liu, Lou and Li (2018, JMVA). We also developed a feature screening procedure for ultrahigh dimensional varying-coefficient Cox model in Yang, Zhang, Li and Huang (2019, JMVA). Change-point problem: We developed a new procedure for homogeneity test of covariance matrices and change-points identification with high-dimensinal longitudinal data in Zhong, Li and Santo (2019, Biometrika). We also developed a consistent selection procedure for the number of change-point via sample-spliting in Zou, Wang and Li (2020, Ann. Stat.). Our work on this topic includes Wang, Peng, Bradic, Li and Wu (2020, JASA), Wang, Cai and Li (2021, JMVA), Liu, Ke, Liu and Li (2022, JASA); Guo, Li, Liu and Zhu (2022, Science China Math) and Cai, Li and Zhang (2022, JMLR),

Dissemination: The PI delievered  19 distinguished lecture or plenary talk in international conferences or workshops, and 41 departmental seminar talks and professional invited talks. We disseminate our work to other disciplines by conducting interdisciplinary research (Liu, et al, 2018, Addictive Behaviors; Buu, et al, 2020, Addictive Behaviors; Trucco, et al,2020, Journal of Youth and Adolescence; Li et al, 2021, Journal of Neuroscience Methods; Cai, et al, 2022, BMC Medical Research Methodology)

Graduate students: This project help the PIs to train 6 female and 8 male Ph.D. students who have graduated. Six of them found jobs in universities, and eight of them found jobs as data scientists in industrials.


Last Modified: 07/30/2023
Modified by: Runze Li
